executiveSummary: Abby Jordan and Becky App pitched eCreamery Ice Cream, requesting $250,000 for 33% equity in their personalized ice cream gift business. Despite having $2 million in total sales since 2007 and being on track for $750,000 this year, all Sharks declined to invest. Kevin O'Leary offered $125,000 for 25% but withdrew when no other Shark partnered with him. Main concerns were the existing investor owning 70%, high customer acquisition costs, dual retail/online operations, and competition risks.
keyDecisions: All five Sharks decided not to invest in eCreamery. Kevin O'Leary initially offered $125,000 for 25% equity (half the requested amount) but withdrew the offer when no other Shark joined as a partner. The entrepreneurs were advised to consider shutting down their retail store and focusing solely on online operations.

actionItems.task: Consider shutting down retail brick-and-mortar store to focus on online business and improve profitability
Explore loan options instead of equity investment to fund production facility expansion
Develop strategy to address high customer acquisition costs ($20 per customer) and improve repeat purchase frequency beyond twice per year

nextSteps: Abby and Becky will need to seek alternative funding sources, either through traditional loans or by renegotiating with their existing investor who owns 70% of the company. They should evaluate whether to shut down their retail operation and focus exclusively on the online gift model to improve margins and scalability.
keyTopics: Personalized ice cream as a gift concept
Business valuation and equity structure concerns
High customer acquisition costs and promotional challenges
Retail vs online business model efficiency
